hints.content:
Let's represent $\dfrac{6}{8}$ using a visual model.

![rectangle with 6 of 8 equal parts shaded, with each part labeled 1 eighth](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/cd23df65b1e4af77c8942458c19802d7cce786be)

How many fourths will we need to shade to have the same amount shaded as $\dfrac{6}{8}$?

![rectangle with 6 of 8 equal parts shaded, with each part labeled 1 eighth. same sized rectangle below it, with 4 equal parts, each labeled with 1 fourth](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/7e80871c564b814eb7b78351eef77bc62e3cd8b8)

We need to shade $\greenD3$ fourths.

![rectangle with 6 of 8 equal parts shaded, with each part labeled 1 eighth. same sized rectangle below it, with 3 of 4 equal parts shaded, each labeled with 1 fourth](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/5df0da1b0d9bf292e9f082ac0357c8b9304834d3)

 $\dfrac{\greenD3}{4} = \dfrac{6}{8}$
